http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Journalism II is a two-semester course designed to provide students with an intermediate study of media applications above Journalism I. This course can serve as further preparation for advanced media applications. Students in Journalism II will become active participants in the world of media to enhance their communication skills. Students will progress in their academic knowledge through the roles of reporters, photographers, ad sales, and marketing team members. Writing, technology, and visual and electronic media are used as tools for learning as students create, assess, and produce. Students will learn to apply journalistic guidelines for writing and design, which include objectivity, responsibility, and credibility.
Law and Ethics
Students will evaluate legal and ethical issues.
Analyze current legal and ethical issues pertaining to freedom of the press
Determine various legal restrictions placed on the press and electronic media
Explain ethical responsibilities regarding sourcing and technological aspects of media
History
Students will develop knowledge of the history and role of journalism in society.
Analyze the role of journalism in a democratic society
Analyze the impact of journalism on contemporary events

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., call to action, credibility of the media, how journalism shapes outcome of current events, policy, public opinion)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Analyze the impact of photography in contemporary journalism

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., emotional connection, how photos enhance text, reader response)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Management and Organization
Students will demonstrate a working knowledge of staff management and organization.
Apply organizational and time management skills necessary to meet staff production schedules
Apply the existing staff plan for financing media productions
Apply the existing staff plan to maximize the circulation of the media
Design and Production
Students will create designs for media.
Apply the available technologies used in publishing to create appropriate media
Apply design principles and trends for media production

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., color harmony, column layout, graphic effects, typography, Web design)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Analyze content for selected media through reporting, writing, editing, photography, layout, and design
Writing
Students will create various pieces of journalistically sound writing.
Write original interview questions, using advanced research skills in various forms of writing

Write a variety of original journalistically sound pieces suitable for publication (e.g., basic features, basic news, poetry, secondary coverage):
  • captions
  • headlines
Self-edit a variety of original pieces suitable for publication

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., basic features, basic news, captions, headlines, poetry, secondary coverage)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Revise a variety of original journalistically sound pieces suitable for publication

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., captions, headlines, basic news, basic features, secondary coverage)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Photography
Students will demonstrate a working knowledge of photographic principles.
Produce visual content for media
Analyze the role of photojournalism within media
